title: Function Concepts-Tabular and Analytical: Rational, Part C

content.description:

<math alttext="f open parentheses x close parentheses" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math>

<math alttext="4" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn></math>

<math alttext="6" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn></math>

<math alttext="9" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>9</mn></math>

<math alttext="13.5" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>13.5</mn></math>

<math alttext="20.25" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>20.25</mn></math>

<math alttext="30.375" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>30.375</mn></math>

The domain of <math alttext="f" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> consists of the six real numbers <math alttext="1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn></math>, <math alttext="3" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn></math>, <math alttext="4" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn></math>, <math alttext="5" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn></math>, and <math alttext="6" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn></math>. The table defines the function <math alttext="f" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> for these values. The function <math alttext="g" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>g</mi></math> is given by <math alttext="g open parentheses x close parentheses equals fraction numerator 12 open parentheses x minus 2 close parentheses over denominator open parentheses x plus 2 close parentheses open parentheses x minus 5 close parentheses end fraction" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>g</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>12</mn><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mrow><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></math>.
content.question:
Part C

(i) Use the table of values of <math alttext="f open parentheses x close parentheses"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> to determine if <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> is best modeled by a linear, quadratic, exponential, or logarithmic function. 

(ii) Give a reason for your answer based on the relationship between the change in the output values of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> and the change in the input values of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math>.

frqParts.text:
Part C

(i) Use the table of values of <math alttext="f open parentheses x close parentheses"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> to determine if <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> is best modeled by a linear, quadratic, exponential, or logarithmic function. 

(ii) Give a reason for your answer based on the relationship between the change in the output values of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> and the change in the input values of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math>.

topic.text: 2.5: Exponential Function Context and Data Modeling

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Construct new functions, using transformations, compositions, inverses, or regressions, that may be useful in modeling contexts, criteria, or data, with and without technology.
